newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugoslavia beet crop seen meeting domestic needs.
newsitem.headline: Yugoslavia beet crop seen meeting domestic needs.

text.p: Yugoslavia will have enough sugar for domestic needs until the 1998 beet harvest and so will not need to import, the Yugoslav association of sugar producers Jugosecer said on Wednesday.

"Average yield on around 55,000 hectares under sugar beet is expected to be 35 tonnes per hectare, which would give some two million tonnes of beet," Jugosecer Director Milovan Milovanovic told Reuters.
That would allow production of some 210,000 to 220,000 tonnes of sugar.
"Together with around 80,000 tonnes of surplus, this will be enough for regular supply of the domestic market until the 1998 campaign," said Milovanovic.
Annual sugar consumption in Yugoslavia is estimated at around 280,000 tonnes.
Imports of some 180,000 tonnes of refined and brown sugar last year stifled production in Yugoslavia's 15 refineries with a processing capacity for around 4.5 million tonnes of beet.
As a result, sugar beet area this year was well below the official target of 100,000 ha.
Another reason for the shortfall in sowing was a delay in payments to farmers for last year's crop.
The 1996 beet area of some 70,000 ha yielded 2.391 million tonnes of beet. Sugar production was around 270,000 tonnes last year.
According to official statistics, Yugoslavia's 1997 beet area is 56,000 ha.
Beet had to be resown on some 20,000 ha in late April and early May after cold weather and frost damaged emerging crops.
Heavy storms between June 17 and 22 were reported to have slightly damaged the crop in some parts of Serbia.
Milanovic said beet tests would be conducted in August.
